subject: Re: [junit] Javadocing test case and other test classes?
msgSnippet: For my API-level tests, rarely.  Most of them are, as Mike indicates, bare of method-level javadoc, the test name suffices. For the tests that involve business
messageBody:
For my API-level tests, rarely. Most of them are, as Mike indicates,
bare of method-level javadoc, the test name suffices.

For the tests that involve business logic, sometimes. The case I'm
testing is sometimes complex enough that it's difficult to tell which
information is related to the condition I'm testing, and which data is
'required' data, but has no affect on the unit under test. For those
tests, a word or two about just what the heck is going on is very
helpful, even when the test name is 80 characters long.

The wide majority of tests are undocumented and simple, which is the
way I think it should be. But when you need it, you really need it.

-Kevin

On Wed, 05 Jan 2005 14:41:42 -0500, J. B. Rainsberger
<jbrains@...> wrote:
>
> Kevin Klinemeier wrote:
> > Does that mean that you don't include a coment for the test method?
> > FWIW again, I always include javadoc of the methods in my test
> > classes, with a description of what the setUp is setting up, or what
> > the test method is intended to do.
> >
> > >From that point of view, if you're delivering the unit tests, and
> > expecting them to do anything with it, I'd think you'd want to deliver
> > the javadoc as well.
>
> Kevin, when you deliver these Javadocs, do you find that they say
> anything useful that the code doesn't already clearly convey? When I've
> done it in the past, I've found that the Javadocs merely restate the
> code in English, and those are the kinds of comments I find useless,
> even distracting.
